Description: On October 25, 2004, a Notice of Violation and Proposed Imposition of Civil Penalty in the amount of $44,400 was issued for two willful Severity Level II violations (assessed $28,800 for three occurrences of failure to adhere to emergency procedures and $9,600 for failure to perform an adequate survey) and a willful Severity Level III violation ($6,000 for failure to provide an individual radiation monitoring device) related to an event involving personnel entering an irradiator when the source was stuck in an unshielded position.

Primary Offense: drug or medical equipment safety violation
Description: Baxter Healthcare Corporation agreed to pay $18.158 million to resolve its criminal and civil liability arising from its alleged failure to follow current Good Manufacturing Practices when manufacturing sterile drug products. The resolution included a deferred prosecution agreement and penalties and forfeiture totaling $16 million and a civil settlement under the False Claims Act with the federal government totaling approximately $2.158 million.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Gambro Healthcare was required to pay more than $350 million in criminal fines and civil penalties to settle allegations of healthcare fraud in the Medicare, Medicaid and TRICARE programs. As part of this comprehensive global resolution, Gambro Supply Corporation, said to be a sham durable medical equipment company and a wholly owned subsidiary of Gambro Healthcare, admitted to the execution of a healthcare fraud scheme and agreed to plead guilty to criminal felony charges, pay a $25 million fine and be permanently excluded from the Medicare program.

GAMBRO Healthcare, Inc. and its subsidiary GAMBRO Healthcare Laboratory Services Inc. agreed to pay $40 million to settle allegations of healthcare fraud. GAMBRO and another subsidiary, Dialysis Holdings Laboratory Services, Inc., also agreed to pay more than $13.1 million to settle similar allegations.

Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General

Private Litigation Case Title: Pilarcita Sayaman et al v. Baxter Healthcare Corporation et al

Description: Agreed to pay a $75,000 civil penalty and $20,000 to a wetland restoration fund in settlement of alleged water pollution violations.
Baxter Healthcare Corp. agreed to pay $6.8 million in settlement of average-wholesale-price misreporting allegations.

Baxter Healthcare Corporation, a subsidiary of global healthcare company Baxter International, Inc. agreed to pay $2 million in settlement of alleged improper reporting of the average wholesale price of its drugs, causing Medicaid to overpay.
falsification of wholesale drug price reporting
Info Source: Attorney General Abbott Wins $8.5 Million Settlement in Civil Medicaid Fraud Case, US States News, June 12, 2006 (via Nexis).

Description: misreporting average wholesale drug prices to Medicaid

The Alabama AG announced that a group of six pharmaceutical companies agreed to pay a total of $89 million to settle litigation relating to Medicaid average wholesale prices. The amount to be paid by each company was not revealed. Here we assume the total was divided equally among them.
Info Source: Associated Press, Ala. settles suits with 6 drug firms for $89M, May 22, 2009 (via Nexis).

Description: A group of seven pharmaceutical companies agreed to pay Iowa a total of $4.3 million to settle a lawsuit alleging false reporting of average wholesale prices, thus increasing costs for the state's Medicaid program. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among them.
Notes: Abbott Laboratories, Inc.; Amgen, Inc.; Baxter International, Inc. (and associated companies); Ben Venue Laboratories, Inc.; Boehringer Ingelheim Roxane, Inc. (and associated companies); Immunex Corp.; and Roxane Laboratories, Inc. collectively agreed to pay $2.5 million in settlement

Info Source: Attorney general, Gambro reach agreement on antitrust lawsuit, Associated Press, July 12, 2000 (via Nexis).

Description: Gambro agreed to pay $37.5 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it improperly billed state Medicaid programs for home dialysis services.
Info Source: Attorney General Nixon Recovers $974,182 in Settlement with Company that Improperly Billed Medicaid for Dialysis Services, US States News, September 20, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced settled charges and an $18 million penalty against Baxter International Inc. for engaging in improper intra-company foreign exchange transactions that resulted in the misstatement of the company's net income.
